sections.title: Relief for clenching, grinding, and jaw fatigue
sections.body: We investigate what is driving your bruxism—stress, bite imbalance, or airway concerns—and plan conservative measures first. Guards and therapeutic options are considered when clinically justified.
bullets: Detailed assessment of wear patterns, muscle tenderness, and bite alignment
Custom night or day guards when indicated to protect teeth and joints
Advice on habit change, posture, and when therapeutic injectables are appropriate

sections.title: Conservative-first planning
items: History includes stress factors, sleep quality, medications, and dental work
We check muscle tenderness, jaw range, and wear facets before prescribing
3D scans or impressions for precise guard fabrication when needed
Referral for physiotherapy, sleep medicine, or imaging when symptoms warrant it

sections.title: Understand triggers and protect your teeth
sections.body: We map your symptoms, check occlusion, and discuss lifestyle factors that may worsen clenching. Where appropriate, we plan a guard, adjust existing restorations, and outline when therapeutic injectables might support muscle relaxation.
bullets: Medical and dental history including pain patterns and headaches
Examination of muscles, joints, and tooth surfaces
Guard options explained with pros, cons, and maintenance guidance
When to trial physiotherapy or habit coaching before medication
Clear review schedule to monitor comfort and fit

sections.title: Patients experiencing clenching symptoms
items: Jaw ache or tension on waking or during concentration
Chipped, worn, or flattened tooth surfaces
Tension headaches linked to clenching or grinding
Previous dental work needing protection from heavy bite forces
Patients seeking a structured plan before considering injectables

sections.title: Assess, protect, review
items: Consultation with bite, muscle, and joint assessment
Plan self-care and habit changes; consider physiotherapy input
Fit a custom guard if indicated; adjust bite or restorations as needed
Consider therapeutic injectables for muscle overactivity where appropriate
Follow-up to review comfort, wear, and symptom changes
Escalate to imaging or specialist referral if pain or locking develops
sections.strapline: Timelines depend on symptom severity and how you respond to conservative steps.

sections.title: Look after your jaw and guard
items: Clean and store guards as advised; bring them to reviews for checks
Follow exercises or relaxation techniques recommended by your clinician
Avoid chewing hard foods while adjusting to guard use
Seek prompt review if you notice locking, swelling, or new bite changes

sections.title: Plan joined-up care
items: TMJ disorder treatment with conservative-first approach (/treatments/tmj-disorder-treatment)
Facial pain and headache assessment when symptoms radiate (/treatments/facial-pain-and-headache)
Therapeutic facial injectables for muscle-related symptoms when suitable (/treatments/therapeutic-facial-injectables)
Night guards (occlusal splints) tailored for clenching and grinding protection (/treatments/night-guards-occlusal-splints)

faqs.question: Do all patients need a guard?
faqs.answer: Not always. We only prescribe a guard when examination shows it will help protect teeth or joints. Some cases respond to self-care and lifestyle adjustments alone.

faqs.question: When are injectables considered?
faqs.answer: Only after assessment and conservative steps. They may be offered to relax overactive muscles when clenching causes pain or wear and you are medically suitable.

faqs.question: How long does a guard last?
faqs.answer: Lifespan depends on forces and care. We review wear and fit at follow-ups and can adjust or remake when needed.

faqs.question: Can bruxism damage other dental work?
faqs.answer: Yes. We check crowns, implants, and fillings during assessment and plan protection to reduce the risk of fractures or loosening.

faqs.question: When should I seek urgent help?
faqs.answer: If you experience sudden jaw locking, swelling, or severe pain, contact us or emergency services for urgent review.

sections.title: Book a bruxism assessment
sections.body: Discuss clenching, tooth wear, and jaw tension with a clinician who prioritises conservative care and safety.
